security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based documentation skill containing only markdown guidance for error handling best practices. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond reading the skill file itself.

content.user_title: Implement error handling patterns in code
content.value_statement: Poor error handling leads to silent failures, frustrated users, and hard-to-debug issues. This skill provides patterns and best practices for robust error handling in async code, API calls, and React components.
actual_capabilities: Prevents empty catch blocks with mandatory logging
Creates user-friendly error messages that avoid technical jargon
Implements React Error Boundaries to isolate component failures
Provides graceful degradation patterns for partial failures
Defines custom error classes for different error types
Handles Promise errors and async operations safely
limitations: Does not execute error handling code - provides guidance only
Does not integrate with specific error tracking services
Does not auto-generate error handling code from specifications

use_cases.title: React Error Boundaries
use_cases.description: Add error boundaries to React components to prevent crashes from spreading across the UI.

use_cases.title: API Error Handling
use_cases.description: Handle API failures with proper error types, user messages, and logging strategies.

use_cases.title: Async Error Patterns
use_cases.description: Manage Promise rejections and async operations with fallbacks and retry logic.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Error Handling
prompt_templates.scenario: Add error handling to async function
prompt_templates.prompt: Add proper error handling to this function. Include try-catch with logging, user-friendly error messages, and fallback behavior.

prompt_templates.title: Error Boundary Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Error Boundary component and wrap the following components. Provide a user-friendly fallback UI and error logging.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Error Classes
prompt_templates.prompt: Define custom error classes for different API error scenarios including NetworkError, NotFoundError, and ValidationError with appropriate status codes.

prompt_templates.title: Graceful Degradation
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement graceful degradation for this feature. Add multiple fallback layers: primary source, secondary source, cached data.

output_examples.input: Add error handling to a data fetching function
output: Log errors for debugging with full context
Show user-friendly message without technical details
Return fallback data when primary source fails

best_practices: Never leave catch blocks empty - always log errors at minimum
Distinguish between error types and handle each appropriately
Show users friendly messages - never expose technical error details
anti_patterns: Empty catch blocks that silently ignore all errors
Exposing raw error messages or stack traces to users
Using generic error messages that do not guide users to resolution

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It provides error handling guidance for any coding task.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with error tracking services?
faq.answer: The skill shows patterns for error tracking integration but does not connect to specific services like Sentry or Rollbar.

faq.question: What error types are covered?
faq.answer: The skill covers network errors, validation errors, authentication errors, not found errors, and general application errors with custom classes.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code. It only provides coding guidance.

faq.question: How does it handle async code?
faq.answer: The skill includes patterns for Promise error handling, async/await error catching, and Promise.allSettled for multiple concurrent operations.

faq.question: What React patterns are included?
faq.answer: React Error Boundary implementation, component-level error isolation, fallback UI components, and error logging in component lifecycle methods.
